description: The largest polis in Aristeia, a city-state of progressive thinkers, pious thaumaturges, and wise oracles. Wiki
A warrior polis high in the Katachthon Mountains, inspired by Sparta. The Akroans are known as the most feared warriors in Aristeia, living and dying by the spear in the name of countless kings. Wiki

A polis located in Melini's Nessian Forest, inspired by Themiscyra. Composed primarily of women and children, it is the favored polis of Karametra. Setessa encompasses a sprawling area with tree-like rings radiating from the Temple of Karametra at its heart. Wiki

A labyrinthine city of the minotaurs in Aristeia, described as a dark reflection of Akros. The city is a maze carved from red sandstone, with homes, shops, fortresses, and temples built into the caverns' walls. Wiki
Tethmos is the primary leonin den and capital city of Oreskos, high in the mountains. Wiki
A necropolis in the Despair Lands, devoted to Phenax. Asphodel is a desolate city, a collection of decaying ruins known for its lack of hope and despair. Wiki
More accpeting of outsiders than Asphodel, Odunos is still a bleak city, but for those looking for dark magic and forbidden knowledge, Odunos may be the best start.
A coastal city-state in Aristeia known for its maritime prowess and trade networks. Wiki
Description of the location, accepts commas and tags

The Merchant Kings of Pytharis are a far cry from the warriors of Akros and the philosophers of Meletis. They are known for their cut-throat trade practices, and unlike other Aristeians, they would choose gold over honor every time.
The great merfolk city of Aristeia, the majority of the city is located in the crystal-clear waters of its bay.
A country respite for the aristocrats of Meletis, Oxus is a growing town with an influx of outside investment.

Description Pending. I'll get to it eventually. Most likely.
Piracy. No town is more associated with it in Aristeia than Latchkey. The beachside town is littered with sailors of every kind, and those who profit from them.
Great tradeport, known for its hotsprings and thermal pools. Many travelers stop here to relax and recover from their journeys.
The hard-working town of Brigen is known for its prized cattle and grain. The cattle market in town draws traders from all over Aristeia.

Situated along the banks of the Pynx river, and within a day's walk to the Silver Wood and the Syrion Mines, Onux is a thriving town of industry, though lacking the cultural extravangance of Pytharis.
An ancient town on the edge of the desert. Nausipoli is what's left of an ancient and proud desert kingdom.
A humble fishing village far from the spendor of Akros. It is known primarily as the birthplace of hero Daphne, second only to Callaphe the Mariner in fame.
A town of stone masons, Pilea exports marble from the Lyssian Mine to the rest of Aristeia. For every statue of a god or goddess, there is a coin in the pocket of a Pilean.
Smaller than Deyda Harbor, but no less vibrant. Anopoli is a port town responsible for most of Akros's agricultural trade.
A pilgrimage site for the those wishing to consult the Oracles, Orithon is a town of true believers and charlatans in equal measure.
The main port of Akros, Deyda is more than just a harbor now.

The Minotaurs of the Beastlands have no great love of the sea, yet even they know the importance of trade. Krothis is a bustling port of goblins, orcs, minotaurs, and any willing to overcome a natural aversion to water in the name of profit.
Description Pending. I'll get to it eventually. Most likely.
Buckpoint is the last bastion of civilization on the Theanos Peninsula. Filled with pioneers, outlaws, and would-be adventurers, it is a town of opportunity or a town of last resort.

The centaur tribes of the Hornlands rarley build permanent settlements, but the fertile banks of lake Lethys were so frequently used as a campsite that its growth into a town was inevitable.
The port of Asphodel, Vallaki is the first stop for any traveling to the Necropolis, or North into the broken lands.
